qas.question: Which company introduced standard base sizes for incandescent lamps?
In what year were standard base sizes introduced for incandescent lamps?
What are some common technical standards for lamp bases?

answers.text: ANSI standard C81.67 and IEC standard 60061-1

qas.question: What is the typical base type for automotive lamps?
What is the typical base type for halogen lamps?
What cannot be directly soldered to a printed circuit board in many very small lamps?
What do some reflector-type lamps not include for connection of wires?

plausible_answers.text: a multitude of incompatible lamp bases

qas.question: What was introduces in the late 18th century by manufacturers?
Who was not the first to introduce standard sizes for incandescent lamps?
What year was the Mazda trademark rejected?

context: Very small lamps may have the <b5_0>filament support wires<b5_0/> extended through the base of the lamp, and can be directly soldered to a printed circuit board for connections. Some reflector-type lamps include <b6_0>screw terminals<b6_0/> for connection of wires. Most lamps have metal bases that fit in a socket to support the lamp and conduct current to the filament wires. In the late 19th century, manufacturers introduced <b7_0>a multitude of incompatible lamp bases<b7_0/>. <a0_0><b8_0>General Electric<b8_0/><a0_0/> introduced standard base sizes for tungsten incandescent lamps under the Mazda trademark in <a1_0><b9_0>1909<b9_0/><a1_0/>. This standard was soon adopted across the US, and the Mazda name was used by many manufacturers under license through 1945. Today most incandescent lamps for general lighting service use an Edison screw in candelabra, intermediate, or standard or mogul sizes, or double contact bayonet base. Technical standards for lamp bases include <a2_0>ANSI standard C81.67 and IEC standard 60061-1<a2_0/> for common commercial lamp sizes, to ensure interchangeablitity between different manufacturer's products. <a3_0>Bayonet base lamps<a3_0/> are frequently used in automotive lamps to resist loosening due to vibration. A <a4_0>bipin base<a4_0/> is often used for halogen or reflector lamps.
